animalOfTheDay.name: yak
facts: Yak milk is rich in butterfat – churned into butter tea in Tibet.
Their dung is dried and burned as fuel in treeless Himalayan regions.
They grunt instead of mooing; 'yak' mimics their guttural sounds.
Yaks survive at 20,000 ft – lungs and hearts 3x larger than cattle.

calendar.name: wild dog
facts: Packs hold territories up to 900 square miles.
They regurgitate food for pups, elders, and injured pack members.
African wild dogs vote to hunt via sneezing – more sneezes trigger departures.
Wild dogs have mottled coats unique to each individual.

calendar.name: wombat
facts: They can run 25 mph despite stubby legs.
Wombat rear hides have cartilage plates – blocking dingo bites when fleeing to tunnels.
They dig complex burrows with multiple entrances and sleeping chambers.
Wombats produce cube-shaped feces – unique among animals – to prevent rolling.

calendar.name: woodpecker
facts: Acorn woodpeckers drill thousands of holes to store acorns – 'granary trees'.
Pileated woodpeckers create rectangular holes in trees searching for ants.
Their tongues wrap around skulls to cushion brains during pecking.
Woodpeckers have shock-absorbing skulls and compressible brain cases.

calendar.name: woolly mammoth
facts: Woolly mammoths had fur up to 3 ft long and 4-inch fat layers for insulation.
Their curved tusks measured 16 ft – used for clearing snow to reach grass.
Mammoths survived on Wrangel Island until 1650 BCE – contemporary with Egyptian pyramids.
Permafrost-preserved mammoths provide DNA for de-extinction projects.

calendar.name: worm
facts: Earthworms have five hearts and breathe through skin.
They improve soil aeration – moving 20 tons of earth per acre annually.
Worms regenerate segments; some species regrow heads.
Charles Darwin studied earthworms for 40 years, calling them 'nature's ploughs'.

calendar.name: wren
facts: Eurasian wrens build dome-shaped nests with side entrances – males build multiple for females to choose.
The tiny winter wren weighs less than a nickel but sings loudly.
They sing at 10 notes/second – 10x faster than human speech.
Wrens roost communally in winter; 60+ birds huddle in nest boxes.

calendar.name: yak
facts: Yaks survive at 20,000 ft – lungs and hearts 3x larger than cattle.
They grunt instead of mooing; 'yak' mimics their guttural sounds.
Yak milk is rich in butterfat – churned into butter tea in Tibet.
Their dung is dried and burned as fuel in treeless Himalayan regions.

randomAnimals.name: gorilla
facts: They're primarily vegetarian despite their massive size and strength.
Gorillas share 98% of their DNA with humans.
A silverback gorilla is 10 times stronger than an adult human.
Gorillas can learn sign language and have been observed using tools.

randomAnimals.name: numbat
facts: Numbats have a long, sticky tongue that can extend up to 4 inches to catch termites.
They are diurnal, unlike most marsupials, and feed exclusively on termites.
They are endangered, with fewer than 1,000 individuals left in the wild.
Numbats are small marsupials from Australia, also known as banded anteaters.

randomAnimals.name: jerboa
facts: They can jump up to 3 meters (10 feet) high and 6 meters (20 feet) long to escape predators.
Jerboas are small rodents from the deserts of Africa and Asia, known for their long hind legs and ability to jump long distances.
They are nocturnal animals that spend the day in cool burrows to avoid the heat.
They have a very long tail that helps them maintain balance during jumps.
